ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Analytical methods of constitutional law; American history; Political science analysis
How to read the Constitution--different methods, strategies, and proper ground rules for doing so. Also insights into constitutional debates/history of constitution.
I gained a general understanding of the process and thought that went into ratifying and amending the Constitution. I also learned to craft constitutional arguments.
I learned how to think like a constitutional lawyer. I learned what types of arguments constitutional scholars can make, the purpose behind various parts of the Constitution, and more.

How to think as a constitutional scholar (with special emphasis on the text, history, and structure of the Constitution), knowledge of America at the founding, insights about what law school might be like.
Gain an appreciation for the multifaceted study of the Consitution with an emphasis on history, structure, and the text itself.

I gained great insight into the American constitution, especially, its text, history, structure and function. This course also further developed my research skills, by forcing me to look at original documents as opposed to just scholarly articles. Overall, the insights I gained on the American constitution were substantial, and my knowledge on the Constitution and American history is greater because of it.
I learned how to interpret the Constitution.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: None to improve on!

Strengths: Lots of interesting class material, fairly simple format, and great TA's

Weaknesses: Class seminars themselves were too disorganized, more structure could have improved the course.

This course was structured well to promote independent learning. The course was relatively fluid and relied on student engagement to shape what topics we discussed and in what depth. The course would not have been very beneficial for students who did not participate.

Strengths: very interesting subject matter, professor who is an expert in the field, great TAs
Weaknesses: class environment could have been more cohesive and less intimidating

Akhil Amar and his great TA's are the strength of this excellent course. 
There are really no weaknesses, except perhaps the unstructured-ness of class discussions, but even then, the open format allows Amar to cover a much wider range of topics (the readings, discussion posts, student questions, current events, personal stories about important people in the judiciary today) than he might otherwise be able to.

Professor Amar is incredibly knowledgeable, and you will be hard-pressed to find a Professor at the forefront of their field. However, his expertise leads discussions to essentially become lectures where Amar explains things for 3 hours. It can be hard to know what your classmates think or know any alternative interpretations.

Strengths: Content, engagement, short but very informative lecture videos 
Weaknesses: Long discussions, hard to stay engaged the whole discussion period, Length of discussion posts. 
Improvements: 5-10 minute break during 2.5 hour discussions, shorter requirements for the discussion posts.
More structure to class time. Many of the sessions were unorganized lectures from Professor Amar.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, particularly those interested in pursuing law school in the future, or any student interested in understanding America's founding principles and civics.

If one has not Poly Sci or Constitutional background like I did, I would caution them that this is going to be a lot of work and challenging, although it teaches a lot and really is helpful for figuring out whether one wants to go to law school. Those with more background expertise will likely find the level of challenge and information learned to be well balanced.
I would! The class environment can be a bit intimidating, but overall the class is definitely worth it. I learned a lot, and Professor Amar certainly knows his stuff.
Absolutely! Don't miss this opportunity to take a class with Akhil Amar as an undergraduate.

Yes, but you need to a) really like America, b) be prepared to read a lot, and c) understand the limitations of the course. The class is very America-centric and while it does not shy away from discussing the shortcomings of the republic, the class will certainly glorify the US more than other Yale courses. Amar has students read three 500 page books and expects a detailed understanding of the arguments he raises throughout each text. The course only presents (in great detail) Amar's arguments. If you strongly disagree with a take, you can push back, but the course is not really interested in providing a well-rounded view of the Consitution.

Yes I would. I think this course encompasses many important aspects of American democracy and turns them into one fluid learning mechanism. Thus, it allows a student to learn all about the the Constitution, American history and Law in one class.
